title: How to Solve a Rubik's Cube

steps.headline: Familiarize yourself with the Notations at a later step in the article.
Choose one face to start with.
steps.description: In the examples that will follow, the color for the first layer is white. It’s important to note that starting with a color other than white can be confusing if you are just starting. This is because you will have to imagine different colors in place of the ones in this article.

"} Solve the cross. Find the side with the white square in the center and put it on top. Set into position the four edge pieces that contain white. The color that the edges have must line up with both the white center and the center on the sides of the cube. The cross only needs a maximum of eight moves to become solved. (five or six in general). If you put a white edge piece in the correct place but it is flipped around, then try popping it out of the top layer and reinserting it correctly. If you are really struggling, then put the white edge pieces next to the yellow center instead and then rotate each edge piece above its correct center, bringing it down so it is now next to the white center instead. Place the cross at the bottom. Turn the cube over 180° so that the cross is now on the bottom.

"} There are some algorithms if you cannot do it intuitively yet. Try turning the cube so the white is facing up again, and check to see which direction the corner points. If it faces right, you can do R’ D’ R. If it faces you, you can do D’ R’ D R. If it faces down, you can do F L D2 L’ F’. Another common method for solving a corner is to have it above the slot it needs to go in and repeat R U R’ U’ until it is solved. At the end of this step, the first layer should be complete, with a solid color (in this case, white) at the bottom.

steps.headline: Permute the corners.
steps.description:
At this step, our goal is to place the corners of the last layer in their correct position, regardless of their orientation. Locate two adjacent corners that share a color other than the color of the top layer (other than yellow in our case). Turn the top layer until these two corners are on the correct color side, facing you. For instance, if the two adjacent corners both contain red, turn the top layer until those two corners are on the red side of the cube. Note that on the other side, the two corners of the top layer will both contain the color of that side as well (orange in our example). {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/a/a4/Rubik_LL_Corners_Permute_316.png","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/a/a4/Rubik_LL_Corners_Permute_316.png","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":406,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":670.5882352941177,"licensing":"

Rubik's Cube Illustration for permutation of the corners of the last layer.

Image by: Uploader
License: Creative Commons

"} Determine whether the two corners of the front side are in their correct position, and swap them if needed. In our example, the right side is green, and the left side is blue. Therefore the front corner on the right must contain green, and the front corner on the left must contain blue. If it is not the case, you will need to swap those two corners with the following algorithm:Swap 1 and 2 : {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/7/7e/VLU_765.png","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/7/7e/VLU_765.png","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":460,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":760,"licensing":"

steps.headline: Permute the edges.
steps.description:
You will need to know only one algorithm for this step. Check whether one or several edges are already in the proper position (the orientation does not matter at this point). If all the edges are in their correct positions, you are done for this step. steps.headline: Congratulations!
steps.description: Your cube should now be solved.

steps.headline: This is the key to the notations used.
This article uses two different views for the Cube:
steps.description:
The 3D View, showing three sides of the Cube: the front (red), the top (yellow), and the right side (green). In Step 4, the algorithm (1.b) is illustrated with a picture showing the left side of the cube (blue), the front (red) and top (yellow). {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/9/95/Rubiks_Cube_948.png","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/9/95/Rubiks_Cube_948.png","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":460,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":760,"licensing":"

Rubik's Cube with colored edge, corner and center.

Image by: Uploader
License: Creative Commons

"} The Top View, showing only the top of the cube (yellow). The front side is at the bottom (red). {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/a/ae/Rubik_TopView_378.png","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/a/ae/Rubik_TopView_378.png","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":487,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":804.1860465116279,"licensing":"

Top View of a Rubik's Cube

Image by: Uploader
License: Creative Commons

"}

steps.headline: For the top view, each bar indicates the location of the important facelet.
steps.description:
In the picture, the yellow facelets of the top back corners are on the top (yellow) side, while the yellow facelets of the top front corners are both located on the front side of the cube. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/6/60/Rubik_LL_CO_21_332.png","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/6/60/Rubik_LL_CO_21_332.png","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":487,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":804.1860465116279,"licensing":"

Rubik's Cube - Last Layer - Corner Orientation - case 2

Image by: Uploader
License: Creative Commons

"}

steps.headline: When a facelet is grey, it means that its color is not important at the moment.
The arrows (blue or red) show what the algorithm will do.
steps.description:
In the case of the algorithm (3.a) for instance, it will rotate the three corners on themselves as shown. If the yellow facelets are as drawn on the picture, at the end of the algorithm they will be on top. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/4/4f/Rubik_LL_Corners_Orient12_951.png","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/4/4f/Rubik_LL_Corners_Orient12_951.png","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":487,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":804.1860465116279,"licensing":"

Rubik's Cube - Last layer - Orientation of the corners. situation 1 with arrows

Image by: Uploader
License: Creative Commons

"} The axis of the rotation is the big diagonal of the cube (from one corner to the corner all the way on the other side of the cube). Blue arrows are used for clockwise turns (algorithm (3.a)). Red arrows are used for counter-clockwise turns (algorithm (3.b), symmetrical to (3.a)).

steps.headline: For the top view, the light blue facelets indicate that an edge is incorrectly oriented.
steps.description:
In the picture, the edges on the left and right are both incorrectly oriented. This means that if the top face is yellow, the yellow facelets for those two edges are not on the top, but on the side. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/9/98/Rubik_LL_EO_12_218.png","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/9/98/Rubik_LL_EO_12_218.png","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":487,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":804.1860465116279,"licensing":"

"}

First Layer Familiarize yourself with the Notations at a later step in the article. Choose one face to start with. In the examples that will follow, the color for the first layer is white. It’s important to note that starting with a color other than white can be confusing if you are just starting. This is because you will have to imagine different colors in place of the ones in this article. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/7/75/Cube_FLm1cross_incorrect_214.png","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/7/75/Cube_FLm1cross_incorrect_214.png","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":460,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":760,"licensing":"

"} Solve the cross. Find the side with the white square in the center and put it on top. Set into position the four edge pieces that contain white. The color that the edges have must line up with both the white center and the center on the sides of the cube. The cross only needs a maximum of eight moves to become solved. (five or six in general). If you put a white edge piece in the correct place but it is flipped around, then try popping it out of the top layer and reinserting it correctly. If you are really struggling, then put the white edge pieces next to the yellow center instead and then rotate each edge piece above its correct center, bringing it down so it is now next to the white center instead. Place the cross at the bottom. Turn the cube over 180° so that the cross is now on the bottom. Solve the four corners of the first layer, one by one. You should also be able to place the corners without needing algorithms. To get you started, here is an example of one corner being solved:{"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/c/c9/Rubik_example01_step1_246.png","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/c/c9/Rubik_example01_step1_246.png","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":406,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":670.5882352941177,"licensing":"

"} There are some algorithms if you cannot do it intuitively yet. Try turning the cube so the white is facing up again, and check to see which direction the corner points. If it faces right, you can do R’ D’ R. If it faces you, you can do D’ R’ D R. If it faces down, you can do F L D2 L’ F’. Another common method for solving a corner is to have it above the slot it needs to go in and repeat R U R’ U’ until it is solved. At the end of this step, the first layer should be complete, with a solid color (in this case, white) at the bottom. Verify your first layer is correct. "} Last Layer Permute the corners. At this step, our goal is to place the corners of the last layer in their correct position, regardless of their orientation. Locate two adjacent corners that share a color other than the color of the top layer (other than yellow in our case). Turn the top layer until these two corners are on the correct color side, facing you. For instance, if the two adjacent corners both contain red, turn the top layer until those two corners are on the red side of the cube. Note that on the other side, the two corners of the top layer will both contain the color of that side as well (orange in our example). {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/a/a4/Rubik_LL_Corners_Permute_316.png","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/a/a4/Rubik_LL_Corners_Permute_316.png","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":406,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":670.5882352941177,"licensing":"

"} If all four edges are flipped, perform the "H" pattern algorithm from any side, and you will have to perform that algorithm one more time to solve the cube. Congratulations! Your cube should now be solved. Notations This is the key to the notations used. The pieces that compose the Rubik's Cube are called Cubies, and the color stickers on the cubes are called facelets. There are three types of Cubies: The centers (or center pieces), at the center of each face of the Cube. There are six of them, each have one facelet, they always stay in the same place relative to each other. The corners (or corner pieces), at the corners of the Cube. There are eight of them, and each have three facelets The edges (or edge pieces), between each pair of adjacent corners. There are 12 of them and each have 2 facelets Not all cubes have the same color schemes. The colors used for these illustrations is called BOY (because the Blue, Orange and Yellow faces are in clockwise order). Examine the positions of the centers relative to each other, as this is always your color scheme. White opposes yellow; Blue opposes green; Orange opposes red; Orange is to the right of blue if white is facing up. This article uses two different views for the Cube: The 3D View, showing three sides of the Cube: the front (red), the top (yellow), and the right side (green). In Step 4, the algorithm (1.b) is illustrated with a picture showing the left side of the cube (blue), the front (red) and top (yellow). {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/9/95/Rubiks_Cube_948.png","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/9/95/Rubiks_Cube_948.png","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":460,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":760,"licensing":"
